results.title: The Burglar cometh
results.creator_credit: Victorian College of the Arts and Aaron Burton
results.brief_description: A dog, determined to protect its owners’ possessions from a thief, is treated to a lesson in irony. Screened at the Melbourne International Film Festival, 2000.

results.title: The Bunyip and the Green Ban
results.creator_credit: Pip Starr, SKA TV and Campbell Manderson
results.brief_description: A local report on a residents’ fight to heritage list the Gentle Bunyip, an historic house in Clifton Hill. Produced as a news story for SKA TV’s Access News, a grass-roots alternative to mainstream news and current affairs, broadcast weekly on Melbourne’s Community Television station Channel 31 since 1994.

results.title: The Bullets of the poets
results.creator_credit: Gittoes and Dalton Productions, Gultha, George Gittoes and Gabrielle Dalton
results.brief_description: For the last decade in Nicaragua, women have been at the frontline of fighting and won the respect of their male companions both as organisers and combatants. Women have brought about this revolutionary change in attitudes by freeing themselves of the stereotype conventions regarding the place of women in war. The six women profiled in the film are remarkable for their sensitivity and the candidness with which they tell their stories. Though they have all experienced the horror of war, none have been hardened. They release their deepest feelings through poetry, and identify more with humanitarian idealism than political ideologies. Filmed entirely on location in Nicaragua.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gittoes and Dalton Productions, Gultha, George Gittoes and Gabrielle Dalton

results.title: The Bulk Link
results.creator_credit: Scope Films and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The ‘bulk-link’ is the vital bridge from the harvest field to the shipping port- the bulk grain handlers. New techniques in the field, the central storage facilities at the embarkation port have made the bulk link a more economical and efficient process. Photography: Edwin Scragg.

results.title: The Building of Florence Cathedral
results.creator_credit: Mary Hoskins and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: Shows how, by examining works of art, it is possible to learn much about the society that produced them, with particular reference to the building of the Cathedral of Santa Maria del Fiore in renaissance Florence. Commentary by John Larner.

results.title: The Builders
results.creator_credit: James Fitzpatrick and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: An outline is shown of the aid which Australia is giving to her neighbours in South-East Asia under the Colombo Plan. Assistance under the Colombo Plan is given to peoples of all nations and all creeds to help them become self-sufficient technically and economically. Narration by Don Crosbie.

results.title: The Bugaku dance
results.brief_description: An introduction to “Bugaku” or Japanese Imperial Court dance and music, which have been preserved in the Imperial Court for centuries. It contains performances of “Ryoo”, a solo dance played with the use of masks, and “Bairo”, a mass dance. Music only - no narration.

results.title: The Buddhist world
results.brief_description: Reviews the origins of Buddhism through the life, work, and philosophy of Gautama Buddha; gives an understanding of the major doctrines of Buddhist belief; traces the historical and cultural growth of Buddhism, and shows its influence in those lands where it is practiced today - India, Thailand, Japan and Tibet.

results.title: The Buddha of suburbia
results.creator_credit: Kevin Loader, BBC-TV and Roger Michell
results.brief_description: A four-part British miniseries about the life of the Amir family who live in the suburbs of 1970s London, and in particular, Karim (Naveen Andrews) whose whole teenage existence is turned upside down during this decade of sex, drugs, politics, racism and rock ‘n’ roll. Karim’s mother Margaret (Brenda Blethyn) is English, his father Haroon (Roshan Seth) is Indian and he has a younger brother Allie (Assam Mamodeally). The family is suddenly thrown into turmoil when Haroon tosses in his job as a civil servant and turns to the life of a suburban guru, leaving his wife and family for the more free-spirited Eva (Susan Fleetwood). The story follows Karim and his relationships as he embarks on a career as a stage actor, weaving from one sub-plot to the next with an array of stereotype characters, situations, humour, including several explicit sex scenes along the way. Explores themes of culture and cross-culture, tradition versus liberation and the anti-Asian racism of London in the seventies. Based on the novel by Hanif Kureishi with screenplay by Hanif Kureishi and Roger Michell. Incidental music and title song composed by David Bowie, performed by David Bowie and Erdal Kizikay. Cast includes Steven Mackintosh, Harish Patel, John McEnery, Janet Dale, David Bamber, Donald Sumpter and Nisha Nayar.
